com.pb.sawdust.io

Class TextFile

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.io.TextFile
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String>

    public class TextFile
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String>
    The TextFile is a convenience class for reading and writing text files.

    For reading, it implements Iterable&lt;String&gt;, providing an iterator over its lines (stripping off the end-of-line characters). This iterator is provided via the IterableFileReader class. The read mode is immune to the specified line separator: all valid end-of-line characters (\n, \r, \r\n) are treated equally.

    Additionally, a persistent read mode may be used, through which the readLine(), readString(int), and skipChars(long) methods may be used. This mode is initiated automatically by calling either of these methods, or explicitly through the openForReading() method. The file remains open for reading until the close() method is called. The readAll() method may be called at any time to read the rest of the file and close it automatically.

    For writing, three modes are offered:

    • "auto flush" - (default) in which every write call opens the file, appends the text, and then closesthe file
    • buffered - this is set by calling setAutoFlush(false); in this mode, all write calls are added to an internal buffer which is only written out when write() is called or auto flush is set back to true
    • open mode - this is set by calling openForWriting(); this opens the file for writing (write calls send the text directly to the file), leaving it open until the close() method is called

    No checks are made to prevent a file opened for writing from being read from, or vice versa; system-specific issues may cause exceptions to be thrown if reading and writing is performed simultaneously. Intermixing writing or reading modes (simultaneously) may also cause problems and is generally not recommended. Attempting to open two line iterators from the same TextFile (without closing them in-between) is explicitly forbidden and will throw an error.

    Note that care should be taken when writing with some character sets, as this class's methods will often (depending on the mode) open multiple writers during the writing process, which can result in errant bytes be entered into the text. For example, with UTF-16, java will add a byte order mark at the beginning of the encoding; if more than one writer is opened (subsequently or simultaneously) then more than one byte order mark may be inserted, effectively corrupting the text.

        Parameters:
        file - The text file.
        lineSeparator - The line separator for this text file.
        charset - The character encoding to use with this file.
        replace - If true, the file will be replaced if it exists, if false it will be appended to. If the file does not exist, this parameter is ignored.

    • Method Detail

      • setAutoFlush

        public void setAutoFlush(boolean autoFlush)
        Set whether the text file should be in auto flush mode or not. If auto flush mode is on, then all write calls will open the file, write the text and then close the file. If auto flush is off, then write calls buffer internally and will only be written when write() is called. The default is to set auto flush to true.
        Parameters:
        autoFlush - Whether auto flush should be on or off.

      • openForWriting

        public void openForWriting()
        Open the file for writing. All write calls will be sent to the file to be written, though buffering may mean that writes don't appear until close() is called. To appropriately free up resources, close() should be called when all desired write calls have been made. Calling this method more than once without closing in between will have no effect.

      • openForReading

        public void openForReading()
        Open the file for reading. To appropriately free up resources, close() should be called when all desired read calls have been made. Calling this method more than once without closing in between will have no effect.

      • close

        public void close()
        Close an opened text file. If the file has already been closed, this has no effect. If the text file was opened for writing, then this will flush its buffer and close the handle. If this text file has an opened line iterator, it will be closed.

      • writeText

        public void writeText(java.lang.String text)
        Write some text to the file.
        Parameters:
        text - The text to write to the file.

      • writeLine

        public void writeLine(java.lang.String line)
        Write a line to the file. The appropriate line separator will be appended to line when writing.
        Parameters:
        line - The line to write.

      • writeText

        public void writeText(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> texts)
        Write a series of texts to the file.
        Parameters:
        texts - The texts to write to the file.

      • writeLines

        public void writeLines(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> lines)
        Write a series of lines to the file. The appropriate line separator will be appended to each line when writing.
        Parameters:
        lines - The lines to write.

      • writeLines

        public void writeLines(java.lang.String... lines)

      • write

        public void write()
        Write any text that has been buffered by write... calls.

      • readLine

        public java.lang.String readLine()
        Read a line of text. All valid end-of-line characters are consumed when reading the lines (this behavior is inherited from java.io.BufferedReader; the returned line of text will not contain any end-of-line characters.
        Returns:
        a line of text, or null if the end of file has been reached.

      • skipChars

        public void skipChars(long charsToSkip)
        Skip characters in the file. If the file has not been opened for reading yet, it will be opened automatically, and must be closed explicitly by calling close().
        Parameters:
        charsToSkip - The number of characters in the file.

      • readString

        public java.lang.String readString(int chars)
        Read a string of a given length from this file. If the file has not been opened for reading yet, it will be opened automatically, and must be closed explicitly by calling close(). The returned string will be at most the number of requested characters long; it will be shorter if the end of file is reached before the desired string length is reached.
        Parameters:
        chars - The (maximum) number of characters to read.
        Returns:
        a string that is at most chars long, or null if the end of the file has been reached.

      • readAll

        public java.lang.String readAll()
        Read the entire text file into a string. If the file is already opened for reading (not including a line iterator), this method will read the remaining unread text in the file. The file will be closed for reading when this method completes, so calling close() is not necessary.
        Returns:
        the text in this file, or the remaining unread text if it is already opened for reading.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.String> iterator()
        Get an iterator which will iterate over the lines in this text file. The line separator specified when constructing this instance is effectively ignored: all valid end-of-line characters are consumed when reading the lines (this behavior is inherited from java.io.BufferedReader. When the iterator is finished, the file handle will automatically be closed. Calling close() before this iterator is finished will close the file handle and (effectively) this iterator. Thus, if an iterator is not to be used to completion, the close() should be called to free the file resource.

        Calling this method again before a previously created iterator has been closed will lead to an exception being thrown.

        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.String>
        Returns:
        an iterator iterating over the lines in this file.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if an unclosed iterator from this file already exists.
